docs.lead_paragraph: The pill, made by Gilead Sciences, is criticized by AIDS activists who contend the $28,500 annual cost is too expensive.

headline.main: F.D.A. Approves Once-a-Day Pill for H.I.V.
headline.print_headline: F.D.A. Approves Once-a-Day Pill for H.I.V.

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves a new once-a-day HIV treatment from Gilead Sciences that contains four different drugs in one pill; AIDS activists contend the $28,500 annual cost is too expensive.
docs.snippet: The pill, made by Gilead Sciences, is criticized by AIDS activists who contend the $28,500 annual cost is too expensive.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chemicals in everything from canned food to A.T.M. receipts could affect you, your children and your children’s children.
docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column warns that there is growing evidence that chemicals like bisphenol-A, found in everyday items, could be hazardous to everyone's health; observes that chemical companies have blocked any serious regulation of such substances.
docs.snippet: Chemicals in everything from canned food to A.T.M. receipts could affect you, your children and your children’s children.

docs.lead_paragraph: New biomedical discoveries may bring a steeper increase in life span — but not everyone wants it.

headline.main: How Long Do You Want to Live?
headline.print_headline: How Long Do You Want to Live?

docs.abstract: News analysis; new research on DNA and other bio-dynamics may offer dramatic boosts to longevity; the possibility raises a very basic question, focusing on whether everyone would really like to live far beyond what is considered a natural lifespan.
docs.snippet: New biomedical discoveries may bring a steeper increase in life span — but not everyone wants it.

docs.lead_paragraph: Chewing gum, coffee grounds and other common items could help you fight ailments while you’re away.

headline.seo: Sick on the Road? Try the Grocery Store
headline.main: Sick on the Road? Try the Grocery Store
headline.print_headline: Sick on the Road? Go to the Grocery Store

docs.abstract: Christine Negroni The Getaway column offers tips for finding home remedies to ailments and minor injuries while traveling.
docs.snippet: Chewing gum, coffee grounds and other common items could help you fight ailments while you’re away.

docs.lead_paragraph: The treatment, being tested by Eli Lilly, failed to halt progress of the disease, but there were some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.

headline.seo: Mixed Results in Lilly Test of Alzheimer’s Drug
headline.main: Alzheimer’s Drug Misses Goal, but Offers Hint of Potential
headline.print_headline: Alzheimer’s Drug From Lilly Misses, but Offers Promise

docs.abstract: Alzheimer's drug solanezumab being tested by Eli Lilly fails in its main goal of halting progress of the disease, but firm says there are some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.
docs.snippet: The treatment, being tested by Eli Lilly, failed to halt progress of the disease, but there were some signs it could slow cognitive decline in patients with mild cases.

docs.abstract: A new study shows that bariatric surgery not only produced sustained weight loss in obese men and women but substantially reduced their odds of developing Type 2 diabetes.
docs.snippet: A new study shows that bariatric surgery not only produced sustained weight loss in obese men and women but substantially reduced their odds of developing Type 2 diabetes.

docs.lead_paragraph: The $716 billion that Mitt Romney has promised to restore to hospitals and insurers would hasten the program’s insolvency, some experts say.

headline.seo: Costs Seen in Romney’s Medicare Savings Plan
headline.main: Patients Would Pay More if Romney Restores Medicare Savings, Analysts Say
headline.print_headline: Patients Would Pay More if Romney Restores Medicare Savings, Analysts Say

docs.abstract: Some health care experts say the $716 billion that Mitt Romney has promised to restore to hospitals and insurers would hasten Medicare's insolvency by eight years, to 2016 from 2024; say restoring reimbursement cuts would add hundreds of dollars a year to out-of-pocket expenses for beneficiaries.
docs.snippet: The $716 billion that Mitt Romney has promised to restore to hospitals and insurers would hasten the program’s insolvency, some experts say.
